Quick bit of Deutsche grey on CS

PM

Mind the RoTE Gap
Although CS could offer mid-term value, we expect low-to-mid-single digit
RoTEs during the restructuring phase (2016-17). Although the stock trades at
c0.8x for a 2018 RoTE of

10%, we believe that there are unlikely to be any

meaningful positive catalysts. If anything, our forecasts are significantly below
consensus in 2016, albeit broadly in-line in 2017 driven by front-loading of
litigation, restructuring and wind-down losses. We downgrade our PT from
SFr22 to SFr18 and maintain our Hold rating.
Updated model, on new decentralized structure
We have updated our CS model, based on the new, decentralized divisional
split. Overall, our 2018 underlying Group PBT forecast of SFr6.7bn is
meaningfully below management ambition of SFr9-10bn. Our forecasts over
2016-17 also remain below consensus, a function of assuming top-end of
contingent litigation risks (SFr1.9bn) as well as the cost of SRU deleveraging
(c3% of RWAs). This drives a low-to-mid-single digit RoTE over the key
restructuring years of 2016-17E, consistent with UBS guidance at the start of
its restructuring program.

PM

Where are we more cautious?
Our divisional forecasts are most cautious for APAC where we believe that the
exit revenue run-rate for 2015 is more relevant than the entry rate; 1H15
revenue was up c35% yoy which we do not see as sustainable. We also have a
more cautious view on Global Markets and IBCM, in the context of CS FICC’s
franchise bias to Credit, Emerging Markets and Securitised Products.
What to expect for 4Q15 results?
Following UBS results, we believe that the focus will be on the impact of
challenging market conditions on WM margins and net new flows. We
forecast total Private Banking AuM down 6% in 2015, with a further 2%
negative performance effect year-to-date. In the absence of gross margin
improvement, this implies significant operating earnings headwinds into 2016.
We also expect focus on APAC where notable strength in the Structured
Products business were a significant driver in 1H15. The market will likely also
be looking at disclosure on energy exposure – see our recent Energy Risks -
Read-through from US banks report.

11:10 am
PM

Valuation/Risk
We use average of sum-of-the-parts and dividend discount model to value CS.
We use CoE of 11% to reach TP of SFr18. CHF strength/tax amnesties
represent major downside risks, as do weakness in Emerging Markets. CS is
exposed to market risk to a greater extent than its peers, thanks to its capital
markets heavy mix of investment banking and private banking. Conversely,
better market risk trends represent upside risks, as would a successful new
cost-led strategy under the new CEO.

BE

Yeah, we have a strategic review of manganese (ie, sacking a lot of South Africans)

BE

BE

Mining's now restarting there but on a lower production rate, so one would assume a lower headcount.

11:21 am
BE

Let me get some grey. Deutsche will do.

BE

S32 has announced that significant headcount reductions are underway across
the SA and Aus manganese, Worsley, Illawarra, and Cerro Matoso operations.
Details will be released with the 1H16 results on February 25. We highlighted
this potential in our recent S32 report. A 20% reduction in labour costs at these
operations contributes strongly to our US$1bn cost-out estimate. Our forecast,
which includes uncontrollable cost reductions, is three times the size of S32's
US$350m target. The majority of the restructuring will be completed by the
end of FY16, confirming the program is ahead of schedule. Our FY16 earnings
have increased due to lower Mn costs and D&A.

BE

A collective 20% reduction in the workforce of the five mentioned assets
would equate to US$175m. The noticeable omissions from the workforce
restructuring are SA coal and Cannington. We think the majority of the
controllable cost-out will come from headcount reductions and lower energy
costs (repricing of Worsley and Cerro Matoso power contracts). Uncontrollable
cost reductions should lift total cost reductions to around US$1bn. When
including asset closures and our weakening FX forecasts, we think the total
cost-out will be around US$1.8bn (reduction in group costs to US$4.6bn).

11:22 am
BE

South African manganese production will be reduced by 0.9Mt (or 23%) to
2.9Mtpa, removing around 2-3% of global supply. We wouldn’t be surprised to
see the 0.5Mtpa PCO2 project at GEMCO commissioned and then put on C&M
also. The workforce in SA will be cut by a third or 620, which will result in a c.
10% reduction in cash costs (50% of costs are rail and port). The one furnace
at Metalloys will remain open as it is now cash flow positive with the weak
rand. Our SA manganese NPV has increased from US$(128)m to US$75m.

BE

A total of US$1.7bn of non-cash write-downs has been booked on lower
prices. Of interest is SA coal, which has been written down to zero. We think
this is due to a negative valuation on WMC prior to the upcoming cost-out. It
may also imply that S32 is now more cautious on the outlook for thermal coal.
In our view this puts the economics of the Klipspruit extension project into
question (not in our numbers), along with any possible M&A in coal.

11:24 am
BE

Before we leave miners, may as well mention Anglo.

BE

Credit Suisse does the maths on a debt reset.

BE

And in the context of how negative the world looks for Anglo right now, I guess the conclusion "they could get out of this, maybe" is a positive.

11:26 am
PM

ha

BE

If management achieve the long term 20 asset vision Anglo margins will improve dramatically, however, this remains a long way off (2+ years). The more pressing issue is
debt; as we highlighted in a recent note (Liquidity watch: time is a
valuable commodity), Anglo has good liquidity, but net debt needs to fall by
up to $7bn from a current level of $13-14bn to less than $10bn based on the current
asset base and on potential asset sales in 2016/17 to less than $8bn. While there is
a strong value case we remain on the side-lines until we see material
progress on divestments and gain greater confidence in a sustained rebound
in diamond volumes and profits heading into 2017.

BE

Is equity needed?: under our base case or spot prices we see a relatively
low chance of the company needing to raise equity given the expected uplift
in cash flows from 2017. Under a downside scenario where prices fall a
further 10%+ (largely wiping out 2017 cash flows), the company would need
to consider more urgent debt reduction measures of at least $4bn which may
require core asset sales as well as equity.

11:27 am
BE

Value case: the shares are trading below 0.3 P/B and our market based
SOTPs valuation is £5/sh or 100% upside. If we put zero value for the entire
iron ore and PGM businesses the shares would still be trading on a P/B of
0.5x supported by the cash generative copper and diamonds divisions. If the
company can make quick progress on divestments and De Beers volumes
recover in 2016/17 our valuation (without assuming higher prices) rises to
£7/sh and would place the shares on an EV/EBITDA of 8.5 2016E.

BE

As we say every day, pretty much, Anglo's volatile because it's being priced to die. Which it might.

PM

China has burned through almost $800bn of its FX reserves mountain since it peaked at
almost $4 trillion in mid-2014. January’s FX data to be released this weekend is set to register
another sharp drop of $120bn (consensus estimate). But at $3.2 trillion, the market remains
content that massive firepower remains to support the renminbi. It does not. Our economists
estimate that when FX reserves reach $2.8 trillion – which should only take a few more months
at this rate – FX reserves will fall below the IMF’s recommended lower bound. If that occurs in
the next few months, expect to see a tidal wave of speculative selling, forcing the PBoC to
throw in the towel and let the market decide the level of the renminbi exchange rate.

PM

And his concluding par...

11:29 am
PM

ates
Finally a chart for the chartists amongst you! Back in the mid-1990s I spent three memorable
years working at Bank America Investment Management, among some of the industry’s finest.
Having previously spent three years as an economist at the Bank of England, I was new to
markets and I let my economic enthusiasm often get the better of me when making
recommendations to fund managers. I remember the head of fixed income explaining to me it
was far better not to try and pick market tops or bottoms but to wait and observe the market
turn, making the trade late rather than prematurely trying to pick the bottom or top. So the
chart below is notable, showing that key 200d and 320d moving averages for the S&P have
just been breached to the downside according to stockcharts.com. If one is looking for key
technical indicators to ring the bell on the cyclical bull market – maybe it has just rung loud
and clear. A renminbi devaluation will only sever an already badly frayed safety rope.

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

Bit of contusion first thing about whether guiding for revenue and core EPS to decline "low-mid single digit" was a warning.

BE

The answer, I think is no. But only because AZ's guidance doesn't entirely make sense.

11:35 am
BE

As Cazenove explains.

BE

On 2016, surprisingly, Astra guided for both Revenues and Core EPS to decline low-mid single digit LC, which when combined with 3% FX headwind on the top and bottom line, implies Core EPS of $3.93-$4.09, with a mid-point of $4.01, which is below the $4.20 level needed to provide 1.5x div cover on Astra’s $2.80 dividend, which has been reiterated. Maintaining 1.5x div cover is a component in AstraZeneca management’s compensation framework, and hence allowing Core EPS to fall below this level is a surprise. The explanation provided was the one-off deal dilution from the recent ZS-Pharma and Acerta transactions, and we understand the remuneration committee may take this deal dilution into account. The 2016 guidance implies Core EPS 5% below what was widely considered Astra’s earnings floor, though in line with consensus of $4.02. With Core EPS heavily driven by ER/OOI, the market may be more focused on the trajectory of product sales. Guidance implies product sales down 4% LC in 2016, which is 2% worse than consensus (down 2% LC), assuming consensus wasn’t already reflecting any FX headwind. Based on the 2016 guidance elements, the quality of Astra’s Core EPS will deteriorate further in 2016, with Externalisation Revenues and OOI now accounting for c.41% of Core EBIT for 2016, vs. 37.5% for 2015, which compares to only 17% back in 2014.

BE

Bottom line: With Q4’15 Core EPS a slight miss as reported, and a 7% miss after adjusting for the tax rate, and of lower-than-expected quality due to higher-than-expected ER and OOI, we see the quarter as disappointing. 2016 doesn’t require significant consensus downgrades on Core EPS, but the fact that Astra can’t make the $4.20 Core EPS floor is also disappointing, even if a key driver of this floor was ER/OOI anyway, and some investors were already looking past this number, and using their own Cash EPS metric (as we do). We also see the market less focused on near-term earnings for Astra vs. large cap peers, with the investment case far more focused on the pipeline. That said, with limited pipeline updates, we don’t see pipeline focused investors having much to get excited about in today's release either, hence, overall, we expect the stock to underperform by around 3% today.

11:36 am
BE

Which was a pretty good prediction, it turned out.

BE

BE

11:39 am
BE

Here's UBS to try and simplify a bit.

BE

AZN guides for total revenues and Core EPS to decline in the low to mid-single digits
(both in LC) and also calls out an additional 3% headwind from FX on both revenues
and sales, this is factoring in dilutive effects from ZS Pharma/Acerta. Externalisation
revenue is guided to be larger in 2016 than 2015. This implies Core EPS in the range of
$3.92-4.09 (vs cons of $4.04) and total revenue of $21.8-23.7 bn, or sales revenue of
max $20.7-22.6bn (vs cons $22.5 bn and UBSe $21.9 bn) assuming Externalisation
revenue of $1,100 mill (vs 2015 $1,057 mill). Additionally, AZN is guiding for core R&D
costs to be at a similar level to FY 2015 – we were hoping for it to moderate from
2015. AZN is also committed to materially reducing Core SG&A costs in FY16, in line
with our expectations for significant cuts. The outlook is broadly in line with our
expectations, though key question for us remains how much AZN can cut back SG&A.

BE

2016 Outlook implies Core EPS of $3.92-$4.09

The Company has received irrevocable undertakings from Imperial College London, Invesco Asset Management Limited acting as agent for and on behalf of its discretionary managed clients ("Invesco"), Lansdowne Partners (UK) LLP and Woodford to vote in favour of each of the Resolutions. These undertakings are in respect of an aggregate of 123,653,784 Ordinary Shares amounting to 89.8% of the issued share capital of the Company.

BE

Here's Stifel.

BE

Woodford, Invesco, Lansdowne and Imperial College currently hold nearly
90% of the stock, and while the relative positions may change (Woodford
seeks to increase to over 20% while the college will contribute relatively less),
the limited free float isn't much changed.

11:49 am
BE

The funds will be used to accelerate and expand the existing investment
policy. Despite raising more cash when previously management had expected
to proceed with existing resources, there seems to be no change to the
'golden triangle' focus on London, Cambridge and Oxford.

BE

We expect further rounds for key portfolio companies. Battery company
Nexeon, IVO's largest private holding, is probably due for a funding round
which should also provide a valuation uplift.

Increased investment in and with key partners like UCL also likely. As we
wrote last month, the trend to universities raising dedicated funds (Oxford
Sciences Innovation and UCL, where IVO is a 50% shareholder in the latter) is
a step further away in holding chains but brings stronger exclusivity over IP. It
may be that IVO will participate significantly in Cambridge's current funding
round.

BE

The key constituents of our target price on a per Imperial Innovations share
basis are 73p for listed investments, 415p for unlisted investments, 82p for
cash, 73p for university relationships and a net -35p for debt, other assets and
liabilities and the present values of costs and gross profits. Combining these
constituent parts of our valuation, we reach a target price of 609p.

Risks: Imperial Innovations currently benefits from the vogue for IP spinouts,
an open IPO market (perhaps no longer?), the support of key UK investors
and a historically unusual willingness to value VC-type investments at a
premium to book value. The key risk to IVO and peers is a refocusing on risk
over potential rewards. A free float of less than 10% is a further risk in share

11:50 am
BE

Less than 10% free float. That's not ideal.

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 1,532, up 94.5 (+6.57%), High: 1,533, Low: 1,481, Volume: 3.75m
11:53 am
BE

I'm going to chuck up some Shell grey rather than waffle, because it's really quite a dull result and the 6% rally is just that.

BE

Barclays:

BE

Having pre-released 4Q numbers, the final RDS results are reassuringly in-line. At $1.9bn, the adjusted net income is at the top end of the $1.6-1.9bn range with cash flow from operations of $5.4bn in the middle of the $4.8-$6bn range given at the time. As we highlighted at the time of the pre-release, Shell has not had a good track record of performing well at the fourth quarter, but in the context of other results this quarter it does appear to have held up relatively well. Guidance for production for 1Q highlights planned maintenance in the Pearl GtL plant in Qatar with the only other news of note the -20% reserve replacement figure, which was heavily impacted by price effects and the stopping of Carmon Creek. As anticipated, there were no new targets ahead of the planned closing of the BG deal on February 15th. Recent actions make it clear that Shell has been resetting the business not only in preparation for a lower oil price environment with less competitive options being stopped, but also for the incorporation of the BG assets. Shell is clearly not exempt from the squeeze in earnings and cash flow faced by the industry but with the acquired assets it is likely to have more levers than most to pull through the downturn. We continue to see the investment case for Royal Dutch Shell as compelling and rate the stock Overweight with a 2750p/sh price target.

11:54 am
BE

There.

undefined
BE

11:55 am
BE

Someone did mention L&G earlier though, which is a Macquarie sell.

BE

PM

(The Rabble won't know about the threatened strike. It was over pensions, but resolved last night -- well, fresh terms will be voted on by NUJ members...)

11:56 am
BE

The annuity business drives the earnings of L&G, even without the capital which
has been reallocated to LGC (Legal and General Capital division), the business
is still 25% of 1H 2015 operational cash and 19% of IFRS operating profit. L&G
is moving to a model similar to peer Rothesay (reinsuring longevity risk and
investing in infrastructure) which gives much lower ongoing earnings. The back
book has benefited from a very benign credit cycle, to which annuity profits are
leveraged. The business is now much more dependent on sales growth
(and continuing longevity reinsurance) to maintain existing earnings.

BE

Legal and General Investment Management (LGIM), has increased earnings by
30% from 1H 2013 to 1H 2015, reflecting asset growth, despite fee pressure on
tracker funds. However, a contradictory view of the business is given by the VIF
(or Value In force) – the DCF of the expected profits of the business – which has
not grown over the same period.

BE

Given the pressures on core markets, UK annuities and passive asset
management fees, the group has been busy growing investments in building and
infrastructure projects. These are adding what we believe is highly correlated risk
to the balance sheet seeking enhanced returns. We highlight speculative
developments such as 1 Central Square which is completed but less than one
half let. Judging the risks within L&G has become much more difficult as the
group invests in builders and even SME direct private placements.

11:56 am
BE

L&G’s share price is now at a premium to the 1H EEV per share including LGIM
of 211p, despite the challenged outlook for annuities. Dividend growth has
helped with 19% in 1H 2015, which we expect will slow significantly during 2016.
The group’s definition of net cash is irrelevant under the new solvency rules, in
our opinion, as these new rules determine capital and cashflow and the group’s
message may become tougher.
We initiate with an Underperform recommendation and a target price of 189p.
We prefer Prudential (PRU LN, £13.68, Outperform, TP: £15.36) and Standard
Life (SL/ LN, £3.64, Outperform, TP: £4.70).

Avanti Communications Group PLC (AVN:LSE): Last: 123.93, down 14.07 (-10.20%), High: 148.00, Low: 122.50, Volume: 421.93k
PM

hehehe

11:59 am
PM

“For five years the fibre lobby has dominated debate about broadband technology and this has diverted attention from an obvious solution to the problems faced by millions of rural or non-urban households.

That solution is satellite broadband.

Ofcom recently concluded that millions of people in the UK are unable to receive speeds greater than 10Mbps. But yesterday the BDUK Market Test Report concluded that Avanti satellite technology delivers reliable, superfast broadband that satisfies the vast majority of customers.

BDUK has given a resounding endorsement of satellite broadband technology as an alternative solution to broadband speeds and rural access. It concludes that satellite technology is commercially sustainable, delivers near universal coverage, and is an effective solution to areas of low density housing (i.e. rural communities).

BDUK has launched a scheme to make free broadband available via satellite to up to 300,000 homes in the UK and as a result of its Market Test Report we expect a strong response to the launch of the satellite scheme which has been allocated £60m of subsidy.

But that is a drop in the ocean. Satellite broadband is available now to 100% of the population at up to 30Mbps and price points from £30 per month and thus it can deliver David Cameron's 10mb Universal Service Obligation.

It is misleading and unhelpful that Ofcom said recently that up to half of rural households will have to wait three years for a minimum broadband speed. All of those homes have the opportunity to get 30Mbps today by satellite. It is time that the obsession with a fibre solution that is not viable in rural areas came to an end.

As a British provider of an immediate solution to a major problem, we stand by to help and urge politicians and regulators to seize the opportunity today.”

BE

Avanti has delivered the strong sequential growth it signalled in the December closing statement. Growth yoy on a reported basis is solid but "continuing revenue on constant FX growth" is probably flat again - excellent visibility into 2H16 incremental revenue allows management to reiterate guidance. We note a robust statement on medium-term liquidity, which has been an overhang for the stock. Sound progress.

Revenue performance: Avanti has delivered on the revenue steer it provided in December's pre-close statement - revenue was up 27.7% qoq on a constant currency basis (having guided to "strong growth" from Q1 into Q2). Reported growth yoy in the quarter of +10.9% compares to -11.6% +36.4% in 1Q16 4Q15, the latter skewed by the large spectrum sale the company did in the fourth quarter. Avanti now has a number of underlying revenue metrics with which to track momentum. We would highlight that: 1. "top 20 customer bandwidth revenue growth" of 44% remains solid (+57.5% +53.7% in 1Q16 4Q15); and 2. the FY16 growth guidance has been reiterated - we turn to this now.

Growth outlook: Avanti first guided for 50% "continuing business constant FC revenue growth" in FY16 at the FY15 results in September and has reiterated the target for the second time in this release. Growth on this measure in the quarter hasn't been explicitly given in the release, but we'd assume it to be unchanged from 1Q16 (which was "flat"). Critically, management now have $40m of new contracts signed with incremental customers in 1H16 that have started to bill from early January. Assuming this revenue is recognised over 1.5 years, the c.$13m of incremental revenue to be recognised in 2H16 goes a long way to validate the reiterated guidance.

Liquidity: Management have gone to some length to qualify its solid liquidity position disclosing that: 1. it has untapped credit equal to $71m across "multiple facilities" (we'd expect this to be a mix of vendor financing, finance leases, unused revolver etc.); 2. the low point of its business plan should still see it have $90m of cash headroom by FY18 year-end (including the $71m of untapped credit); 3. EBITDA improved in 2Q16 and should turn positive in 2H16 on the back of the aforementioned revenue pick-up and flat costs; and 4. with the passage of time, visibility into capex phasing has improved and capex is now being guided to be $100-110m in FY16 (JEFe, $125m) and $70m in FY17 (JEFe, $115m), offering further headroom. Avanti ended 1H16 with $162.6m of cash on the balance sheet.

Costs: Management have previously signalled that FY16 should see mild opex inflation. This is borne out in the results, with yoy aggregate CoGS and operating expenses (excluding depreciation) flat. This serves to validate management's guidance within the release for 2H16 positive EBITDA. Avanti's EBITDA losses improved to only -$0.6m in 2Q16 from -$2.9m in 1Q16 and -$1.8m in 2Q15.

Working capital: Investors will note a large working capital outflow during 1H16 - minus $16.7m (from -$10.7m in 1H15 and +$8.6m in 2H15) driven in particular by debtors (-$11.6m). Management are quick to address the dynamic with helpful commentary that the uptick in debtors was due to invoices issued close to the quarter end, that should be paid early in the second half.
